author: theaquamarine
body: ## Steps to reproduce Create a function which uses `Write-Host`, then use it in `$Function:prompt`. ## Expected behavior Output of `Write-Host` is displayed once. ## Actual behavior Output of `Write-Host` is displayed twice, once before `PS>` and once after. The second appearance disappears on input. ## Environment data PowerShell 6.0.0-alpha.9 on OS X 10.11.5 ``` powershell Name Value ---- ----- PSVersion 6.0.0-alpha PSEdition Core PSCompatibleVersions {1.0, 2.0, 3.0, 4.0...} BuildVersion 3.0.0.0 GitCommitId v6.0.0-alpha.9 CLRVersion WSManStackVersion 3.0 PSRemotingProtocolVersion 2.3 SerializationVersion 1.1.0.1 ``` Expected behaviour is seen on PSVersion 5.1.14393.0 and 6.0.0-alpha.9 on Windows 10 14393.51

comments.author: jpsnover
comments.body:
I don't know if that is a bug not but the problem is that the host calls the prompt function to **get a string** to use as a prompt.  Your function is NOT returning a string which is why the prompt is still "PS>".

Just to be clear - it is totally fine to do all sorts of processing in your prompt function.  
It is just that at the end, you need to return a string if you want the prompt to be different.

comments.author: lzybkr
comments.body:
This is a definite bug, it's quite common to use Write-Host in prompt.

Before Windows 10 Nov update, the only way to use color in your prompt was to use Write-Host, or another terminal emulator like ConEmu that supported ANSI escape sequences.

With the latest Win10 builds, or on Linux/Mac, prompts can return a string with ANSI escape sequences, so they can avoid Write-Host.
